content.description: This the 3rd route from the left on Sayers' Wall. It has the obvious start in the middle of the wall. It involves smearing with good protection. It seems hardest at the start. Move up and left until a solid finish up to the anchor. This is a solid climb and is worth doing.
content.protection: Very well bolted - 5 bolts to a solid 2 bolt anchor.

climbs.name: The Mantel of the Leprechaun
climbs.fa: Mark Tjaden, Marc Aune, and Kathy Carpenter, October 2004.

content.description: This is an easy route for this grade; it could potentially be rated at a 5.9+, but it is a 5.10a/b due to a tricky start and a tough series after a big ledge about halfway up. It is easy to go to the side on the harder portions to make it easier, although this destroys the rating. It is a great warm-up climb.
content.protection: The route has 5 (6) bolts to a 2-bolt anchor. The bolts are pretty new, and very sturdy, but the anchor rings might need some work in the coming years. Although it's an 80 foot climb, the bolts are well placed so that extra pro is not needed.
content.location: The route is on the far north side of Sayers' Wall, just to the left of a group of pine trees. It runs over a large ledge running down to the ground, and the belay can set up just off of the trail.

climbs.name: The Mad Scientist
climbs.fa: Brian Shelton and Stewart Green, September 2004

content.description:
This is a great, fun route just to the right of

Pikes Peak

. There is a long run out to the first bolt, and be prepared to smear, but it is a great climb. The crux comes on a steep slab near the 5th-6th bolt area.

This is a route that is toproped from

The Mad Scientist's

anchors. Instead of following the bolts for

TMS

, go straight at the anchors directly from below them. Start in the gully that is easy climbing. Face the more vertical wall with the right-facing ledge above, and this requires a bit of smearing. The crux is the same as

TMS

but is left of the bolts and can be more challenging if you stay away from the flake to the left. Then, it's easy sailing to the TR from above the flake.
content.protection:
2 anchors at the top - TR from the same anchors as

The Mad Scientist

.
content.location:
Start about 10 feet left of

The Mad Scientist's

beginning.

climbs.name: Electric Swimming Pool
climbs.fa: Joe Corsentino and Brian Shelton, October 2004

content.description: This is a good route; there is no defined "crux" per se/em> except for a portion about 45-50 feet up, in which you have to be handless for a minute. The downside is the route is relatively new, and not very well cleaned; a lot of the handholds break off at rather unfortunate times.
content.location:
IT is located near the northern part of Sayer's Wall, about 20 meters away from

The Mantle of the Leprechaun

. The belayer can stand on the ground just off the trail next to the group of aspen trees.
